Deb reported "About 500 American children and teenagers die in hospitals every year after sustaining gunshot wounds — a rate that climbed by nearly 60 percent in a decade, according to the first-ever accounting of such fatalities, released Sunday…….Eight of every 10 firearm wounds were inflicted by handguns, according to hospital records reviewed by the doctors. They say the national conversation about guns should shift toward the danger posed by smaller weapons, not the recent fights over limiting the availability of military-style, semi-automatic rifles."

Actually both the FBI and CDC have records on homicides by age, the CDC also has records on deaths due to accidents and suicides by age, and both also record types of weapons. Suicides climbed during the recession but deaths due to homicides and accidents have declined, both to record low levels. The large increase reported above would need to be due to shifts in deaths by age, most likely by teens in urban areas.

A promising conclusion in the report above is the attention on the distinction of handguns vs. long guns. Handguns account for less than 40% of the firearms in the US but account for the vast majority of homicides, and per the report above about 80% of accidental deaths, at least in children and teens.

The York man sentenced to death beat the child. I don't think a gun in the hands of the two year-old would have helped.

The robbery in Lebanon, PA involved a 15 year-old and two 19 year-olds. The strong implication is that the two men robbed had set up to buy drugs from the robbers, who, instead, produced a shotgun and took the cash. Why make it easier for crooks like this to get guns?

Those burglaries? One was 15 year-old who confessed, returned the stuff and the neighbor declined to press charges. But guess what the burglars wanted? "A home on Garden Circle was entered Sunday afternoon, and a handgun and jewelry were stolen, police said." Yep, the criminals are happy to disarm the law abiding!

The Harrisburg stabbing? That's "attempted homicide." Do you think the outcome would have been better if either or both men in that fight had a gun on them?

The guy with the $50 bill? He picked it up off the street after the robbers dropped it. Not exactly your hardened criminal.

Lancaster store robbery? Why make it easier for the robbers to get guns?

You make my points for me, Eric.

JWC--

"Mandatory safety training". As a condition prerequisite to the issurance of a CCW, I can live with the requirement of a 4 to 8 hour course. I've take such courses. That said, most CCW holders I know were already trained far beyond that standard BEFORE they obtained their CCW. Hunters must generally also take a hunter safety course in order to obtain or renew their hunting license.

"Mental health evaluations". Intrusive. Big Brotherish. Offensive. Ineffective. And dangerous in a world where "mental illness" is a highly politicized concept, to the point that merely being politically conservative is deemed to be a form of psychosis by the left.

"Legal penalties for irresponsible use." Already provided for under most states' laws.

"Liability insurance." Unnecessary. Only a vanishingly small fraction of gun owners is ever going to be the subject of a negligence claim. And, as a matter of principle, the purchase of insurance should not be a condition prerequisite to the exercise of a fundamental right. Erroneous reporting can destroy careers and lives. Mandatory libel insurance for Joe and Jennifer? "Mandatory" is not "free market" by the way.

JWC--

"Chamber loaded flags." Many guns sold today feature such mechanisms even they are not mandated. I own a gun that has a chamber loaded indicator AND a "this gun is cocked and ready to fire" indicator. But they add mechanical complexity to the gun and can fail. I therefore don't trust them. I VISUALLY confirm whether or not my guns are loaded. Why would someone is too irresponsible to perform a quick, visual "press check" of their gun bother to pay attention to a chamber loaded indicator? The First Rule of Gun Safety is "All guns are ALWAYS loaded."

"Grip safeties." As a veteran Colt 1911 shooter, I'm personally comfortable with grip safeties. My 1911s feature them as does my modern Springfield .45. They aren't for everyone, though, as they alter the handling characteristics of the gun, introduce another element of mechanical complexity, i.e., in some gun owners' minds another potential point of failure (although, like I said, I'm satsified they are 100% reliable in MY guns), and are poorly suited for incorporation into the grips of smaller-framed guns.

"Microstamping". Easily defeated by switching out the firing pin. A process that takes all of 10 minutes.

QP, I don't think the gun owners that report nearly 250K firearms "lost or stolen" annually is a "vanishingly small fraction of gun owners".

Ditto for the FFLs that do the same.
Unfortunately we live in a country where people value having a gun more than they do the lives of our children.

While the Supreme Court ruling in Heller stands as the law of the land, it will be remembered historically along side of Dred Scott & Plessy vs. Ferguson as one of the most idiotic rulings in the history of the court.

The origin of the 2nd Amendment was a ratification debate on the floor of the Virginia legislature. George Mason and Patrick Henry asked James Madison if the Constitution's provisions allowing only Congress to arm and discipline the Militia could result in non-slave-holding states declining to arm the Militias of slave-holding states. They further postulated that since only the President can call forth the Militia, he might decline to do so in the case of a slave rebellion.

Madison wrote the 2nd to appease these concerns.

As to the ill-informed who think the term "people" means "a group of persons" rather than "The body of persons who compose a community, town, city or nation," I would point them to the first line of the Constitution. It reads, "We, the People," the word capitalized as it is throughout the text and in every draft of the 2nd, but yet the Constitution was ratified by state legislatures (Rhode Island tried a popular vote - it was a disaster).

Of course, the debate about Militias was centered on whether a standing army was appropriate for the new nation. It had nothing to do with private ownership of guns, which wasn't even a debated point.

But the NRA is very good at warping history to suit its needs.

Would it help to put your feet on your carry-on, which would elevate your knees enough so that the circulation isn't cut off by the seat edge?

I'm 5'1". They make collapsable or inflatable footrests for people like us. Check out TravelSmith or other travel accessory sited. I have one that folds up to the size of a tablet, but provides a stable platform for my feet, which wouldn't touch the floor otherwise. I always request a window seat, but the footrest slides under the seat in front of me or collapses easily in about a second if I happen to end up with an aisle or center seat and someone needs to get by.

Buying a pair of compression socks or stockings would probably be far more effective and much less odious to your nearby travelers. Getting up and walking around every few minutes would also work. I also like others' suggestion to prop up your feet. Sounds better than what you are doing now.

Slamming the tray table up is another one that can shake one awake.

Bare feet on a plane is just disgusting, yet on long-haul flights, my feet swell up too much to keep my shoes on. Thick, disposable socks come on and my shoes stay under the seat in front of me to put on when I need to get up.

Being 5'2", the seats were not designed for me and unfortunately, if my feet do not have somewhere to rest, I must get up a lot. My feet don't comfortably rest on the floor. I must wiggle and move to stay comfortable. I had an instance of DVT due to a long-haul flight. The six months of blood thinners and now being a paranoid flyer keep me active now. I'm sure my seat mates get annoyed. I make a point to get an aisle seat so my distraction is minimal to them.

Despite the sometimes craziness of flying, I am glad I have the opportunity to occasionally travel to see the world and appreciate all of the interesting people and sites!
